field_edited_text.value:
Hart/Miller Islands



To meet the need for disposal of the
material from the 50-foot channel deepen-
ing project the state has built a contain-
ment site for over 50 million cubic yards of
fill at Hart and Miller Islands just east of the
Back River in Baltimoré County. The main
channel dredging, a federal project, and
the construction and operation of the
containment site, a state project, are
complex and costly and will require a
concentrated effort over the next five to
eight years.

The state, working with federal agen-
cies and local jurisdictions, is also studying
various alternatives for handling spoil from
future dredging projects. Even with the
Hart and Miller Islands disposal capacity of
over 50 million cubic yards, methods for
handling the remaining 80 million cubic
yards expected from Maryland projects
over the next 20 years, will have to be
identified. Possibilities include overboard
disposal of clean material, wetlands crea-
tion, containment, recycling, hauling spoil
inland, and burial in a deep trench of the
Chesapeake Bay.

Highways:

A number of transportation improve-

ments are planned to accommodate the
increased cargo trade that will be moving
through the port. The most important
highway project is the Fort McHenry
Tunnel, which is scheduled to be
completed by 1985. As the final link of
Interstate 95 to be built in the City, the
tunnel will cross the Patapsco River
between Locust Point and Canton provid-
ing expressway access between the port
and East Coast cities. The planned recon-
struction of local streets will also play an
important role in reducing traffic conges-
tion in several areas, thereby improving
access between regional highways and the
port.

Coal Export Terminals:

Spurred by the high cost of oil and the
consequent search by countries for
cheaper alternative fuels, the United States
is experiencing considerable worldwide
demand on its vgst coal reserves especially
for generation of electricity in Europe. It
has been estimated that between 1980 and
the year 2000 U.S. coal exports will increase
by 100 to 200 percent. Due to its proximity
to the coal fields of western Maryland,
West Virginia, Pennsylvania, and Kentucky,
the Port of Baltimore will be a major tran-

dredge materials disposal site - early construction stage



29
